snippet: Daisha Simmons needed to be closer to home to help her single mother and an ailing brother, but the N.C.A.A. and her former university made things tough on her.
abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of The Times column profiles Daisha Simmons, graduate student who has helped lead Seton Hall's women's team to its first NCAA tournament berth in two decades; observes that Simmons struggled to transfer from Alabama to Seton Hall in order to be closer to her family, process that was beset by emblematic dysfunction of the NCAA; adds that Simmons has succeeded with her new team despite helping care for ailing brother and single working mother.
lead_paragraph: Daisha Simmons needed to be closer to home to help her single mother and an ailing brother, but the N.C.A.A. and her former university made things tough on her.

headline.print_headline: For Pawn in Disputed Transfer, a Winning Move
headline.main: For Pawn in Disputed Transfer, a Winning Move
